children: Bite cells seen at the center of this slide (

) are a typical finding in glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency and are characterized by a membrane defect that appears as though a semicircular bite has been taken out of the erythrocyte. The defect is caused by removal of denatured hemoglobin by macrophages in the spleen. A polychromatophilic macro-ovalocyte can also be seen (
